title: 103_hr2328
content: The Act titled "Public Lands Corps Act of 1993" is established for the purpose outlined in the Congressional findings. The Public Lands Corps Act of 1993 aims to utilize young men and women in a Public Lands Corps to conserve natural and cultural resources, benefitting them with education and work opportunities while also addressing the need for labor-intensive rehabilitation and restoration work on public lands and Indian reservations. Youth conservation corps have a proven track record in maintaining these facilities. The Public Lands Corps Act of 1993 aims to utilize youth conservation corps to perform cost-effective conservation work on public and Indian lands, assisting government agencies in research and education tasks. It also aims to expose young individuals to public service and expand educational opportunities. The Public Lands Corps Act of 1993 aims to expose young men and women to public service, expand educational opportunities, and stimulate interest in conservation careers by involving them in conservation work on public lands. The Public Lands Corps Act of 1993 aims to expose young individuals to public service and conservation work on public lands. The Public Lands Corps Act of 1993 defines key terms such as "Corps," "public lands," "qualified youth or conservation corps," and "Indian tribe." These definitions outline the scope and eligibility criteria for programs aimed at offering meaningful work experience and skills development to individuals between 16 and 25 years of age in natural or cultural resource settings. The term "Indian tribe" is defined as any recognized group by the Secretary of the Interior, including Native corporations and groups established under the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act. "Indian" refers to a member of an Indian tribe, and "Indian lands" encompass real property owned or held in trust by Indian tribes. The term "State" includes various regions within the United States. The term "State" includes various regions within the United States, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, Guam, the Virgin Islands, American Samoa, and the Northern Mariana Islands. A "conservation, restoration, or rehabilitation project" refers to projects for preserving natural, cultural, historic, archaeological, recreational, or scenic resources. The Public Lands Corps Program is established. Establishment of Public Lands Corps for young men and women aged 16-25 by the Department of the Interior and Agriculture. Enrollees must be U.S. citizens or residents, have a high school diploma or equivalent, and can join without regard to civil service laws. Secretaries can contract with qualified youth or conservation corps for projects. The Secretaries of the Interior and Agriculture can contract with qualified youth or conservation corps to carry out conservation projects on public or Indian lands. Preference is given to projects that provide long-term public benefits, instill a work ethic, are labor-intensive, can be started promptly, and offer educational opportunities. The Secretaries of the Interior and Agriculture can contract with qualified youth or conservation corps to carry out conservation projects on public or Indian lands. Projects should prioritize long-term public benefits, instill a work ethic, be labor-intensive, start promptly, and offer educational opportunities. Projects must be consistent with relevant laws and policies governing the management of the lands. Secretaries are authorized to provide necessary services and facilities for these programs, including establishing conservation centers. The Secretaries of the Interior and Agriculture can contract with qualified youth or conservation corps to carry out conservation projects on public or Indian lands. They may establish conservation centers with basic standards for health, nutrition, sanitation, and safety, and can make arrangements with the Secretary of Defense for logistical support near the centers. Contracts with State and local government agencies and private organizations may be entered into for the management of the centers. SEC. 5. RESOURCE ASSISTANTS. The Resource Assistant Program allows the Secretaries of the Interior and Agriculture to place qualified college students or recent graduates in Federal land managing agencies for research or technical functions. The program aims to increase workforce diversity and provide opportunities for students from various backgrounds. The Resource Assistant Program aims to augment the workforce of Federal land managing agencies by utilizing college students and recent graduates. Existing nonprofit organizations can also implement the program, and participating organizations must contribute 25% of the total costs for interns. The Resource Assistant program recruits college students and recent graduates to work with nonprofit conservation organizations. Participating organizations must submit an annual report evaluating the program's impact on the agency's mission. Participants in the Public Lands Corps and Resource Assistant program will receive a living allowance not exceeding the maximum allowed for national service program participants. They must also agree to a specified term of service. Additionally, educational benefits or awards may be provided to participants. Participants in the Public Lands Corps and Resource Assistant program may be eligible for national service awards and forbearance on Stafford Loans. Assistants in the program can request forbearance on loans while serving, following regulations set by the Secretary of Education. SEC. 8. Nondisplacement requirements apply to activities of the Public Lands Corps and qualified youth or conservation corps under this Act. SEC. 9. Funding. The Secretary of the Interior and the Secretary of Agriculture can pay up to 75% of project costs on public lands by qualified youth or conservation corps. Nonfederal sources can cover the remaining 25%. No cost sharing is needed for projects on Indian lands. A foundation linked to a Federal land managing agency can contribute to Public Lands Corps project costs. No cost sharing is required for these projects. Funding for programs under this section is available under the National and Community Service Act. Funds available under the National and Community Service Act can be used for programs under this section without any cost sharing requirements. The Secretaries of the Interior and Agriculture are eligible to receive these funds, and there is authorization of appropriations for necessary sums to carry out this Act.
